muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.
muscles.description_en_us:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).
muscles.description_en_us:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Traps (mid-back)
muscles.description:
There is far more to the trapezius muscle than meets the eye. The traps are not just the muscle that sits on top of your shoulders. The traps actually travel a large portion of your spine. When well developed, the traps take on the look of a cobra hood.

The traps are divided into three portions. Those portions are referred to as the superior, medial, and inferior fibers. All three parts serve similar, but different functions.

The traps are divided into three portions. Those portions are referred to as the superior, medial, and inferior fibers. All three parts serve similar, but different functions.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).
muscles.description_en_us:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.description: With regard to desirability, the glutes are gaining in popularity, however the glutes are far more than something nice to look at. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the body and serves many important functions.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Triceps
muscles.description: The triceps are a muscle with three heads, hence the name. Those heads are the long head, lateral head, and medial head. The triceps are traditionally considered a powerhouse due to their overwhelmingly fast twitch. This expression refers to muscle fibers which expend energy quickly, and the triceps are particularly dominant in this trait. The triceps are involved during any pushing movement.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Lats
muscles.description: The lats are a large flat muscle that has origin points at the mid and lower spine, the iliac crest (pelvis), and the ribs. Well-developed lats give the appearance of a wider back, therefore making the waist look smaller.

muscles.description: The forearms consist of many different muscles and the exact number depends on the anatomy book you are reading! Frequently, the forearms are broken down into three main parts: the brachioradialis, the wrist flexors, and the pronator teres.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.
muscles.description_en_us:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.
muscles.description_en_us:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.description_en_us: With regard to desirability, the glutes are gaining in popularity, however the glutes are far more than something nice to look at. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the body and serves many important functions.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.
muscles.description_en_us:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Forearms
muscles.description: The forearms consist of many different muscles and the exact number depends on the anatomy book you are reading! Frequently, the forearms are broken down into three main parts: the brachioradialis, the wrist flexors, and the pronator teres.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). muscles.name: Lower back

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Triceps
muscles.description: The triceps are a muscle with three heads, hence the name. Those heads are the long head, lateral head, and medial head. The triceps are traditionally considered a powerhouse due to their overwhelmingly fast twitch. This expression refers to muscle fibers which expend energy quickly, and the triceps are particularly dominant in this trait. The triceps are involved during any pushing movement.

muscles.name: Traps
muscles.description:
There is far more to the trapezius muscle than meets the eye. The traps are not just the muscle that sits on top of your shoulders. The traps actually travel a large portion of your spine. When well developed, the traps take on the look of a cobra hood.

The traps are divided into three portions. Those portions are referred to as the superior, medial, and inferior fibers. All three parts serve similar, but different functions.

A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.
muscles.description_en_us:

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Biceps
muscles.description: The biceps brachii is one of the most often trained muscles. stereotypically most guys want big biceps - and in practice, this is often true. As is commonly known, the main function of the biceps brachii is elbow flexion (what occurs during a curl exercise). However, the biceps have far more responsibilities than just curls.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Calves
muscles.description: The calves are composed of two muscles, the gastrocnemius, and the soleus. Both muscles are active every time the ankle joint flexes. In other words, the calves are involved every time you take a step, stand up, or jump.

Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Glutes
muscles.description: With regard to desirability, the glutes are gaining in popularity, however the glutes are far more than something nice to look at. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the body and serves many important functions.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Lats
muscles.description: The lats are a large flat muscle that has origin points at the mid and lower spine, the iliac crest (pelvis), and the ribs. Well-developed lats give the appearance of a wider back, therefore making the waist look smaller.

muscles.name: Calves
muscles.description: The calves are composed of two muscles, the gastrocnemius, and the soleus. Both muscles are active every time the ankle joint flexes. In other words, the calves are involved every time you take a step, stand up, or jump.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.
muscles.description_en_us:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Biceps
muscles.description: The biceps brachii is one of the most often trained muscles. stereotypically most guys want big biceps - and in practice, this is often true. As is commonly known, the main function of the biceps brachii is elbow flexion (what occurs during a curl exercise). However, the biceps have far more responsibilities than just curls.

muscles.name: Calves
muscles.description: The calves are composed of two muscles, the gastrocnemius, and the soleus. Both muscles are active every time the ankle joint flexes. In other words, the calves are involved every time you take a step, stand up, or jump.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Lower back
muscles.description: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.
muscles.description_en_us:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.
muscles.description_en_us:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.
muscles.description_en_us:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).
muscles.description_en_us:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Biceps
muscles.description: The biceps brachii is one of the most often trained muscles. stereotypically most guys want big biceps - and in practice, this is often true. As is commonly known, the main function of the biceps brachii is elbow flexion (what occurs during a curl exercise). However, the biceps have far more responsibilities than just curls.

muscles.name: Lats
muscles.description: The lats are a large flat muscle that has origin points at the mid and lower spine, the iliac crest (pelvis), and the ribs. Well-developed lats give the appearance of a wider back, therefore making the waist look smaller.
muscles.description_en_us: The lats are a large flat muscle that has origin points at the mid and lower spine, the iliac crest (pelvis), and the ribs. Well-developed lats give the appearance of a wider back, therefore making the waist look smaller.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Traps (mid-back)
muscles.description:
There is far more to the trapezius muscle than meets the eye. The traps are not just the muscle that sits on top of your shoulders. The traps actually travel a large portion of your spine. When well developed, the traps take on the look of a cobra hood.

The traps are divided into three portions. Those portions are referred to as the superior, medial, and inferior fibers. All three parts serve similar, but different functions.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.
muscles.description_en_us: The erector spinae is another often-misunderstood muscle. The spinal erectors are thought of as the “lower back” muscles. However, the spinal erectors travel the length of the entire spine. The upper fibers tuck under the latissimus dorsi and trapezius, and therefore are not visible to the naked eye.

muscles.name: Glutes
muscles.description: With regard to desirability, the glutes are gaining in popularity, however the glutes are far more than something nice to look at. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the body and serves many important functions.
muscles.description_en_us: With regard to desirability, the glutes are gaining in popularity, however the glutes are far more than something nice to look at. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the body and serves many important functions.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Quads
muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.

muscles.name: Hamstrings
muscles.description:
The hamstrings are the big muscles on the back of your thighs. Together with the quadriceps, the hamstrings make walking and standing possible.

The hamstrings are made up of the following muscles - the biceps femoris (short and long head), the semimembranosus, and the semitendinosus.

The hamstrings are a weak muscle when compared with the quadriceps (front thigh muscle). Both the hamstrings and the quadriceps pull on the knee joint, so if one of those muscles is stronger than the other, then knee problems are bound to arise. A good rule of thumb is to make sure that the hamstrings are 2/3 as strong as the quadriceps. For example, if you can resist 100 lbs with your quads, then you should be able to resist 66 lbs with your hamstrings.

muscles.name: Shoulders
muscles.description:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.
muscles.description_en_us:
For both men and women, the deltoids, also referred to as delts, are a very desirable muscle to build. Well-developed shoulders can give the appearance of a smaller waist (because the shoulders look broader). Therefore, well-trained delts improve the look of the entire physique.

The deltoid has three different heads: anterior (front), lateral (middle), and posterior (rear). Each head has similar functions, but they do have some variance.

muscles.name: Obliques
muscles.description:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).
muscles.description_en_us:
The obliques are made up of the internal and external obliques. 

The internal oblique sits between the transverse abdominis and the external oblique. The origin is from the iliac crest, and the lower part of the pelvis. The insertion is at the linea alba, pubic crest, and the lower 3-4 ribs.

The internal oblique serves the exact same functions as the external oblique - aiding rotation, flexion and lateral flexion of the spine.

The external oblique is visible at low body fat percentages. The muscle appears as a series of diagonal lines connecting to the six-pack.

The external oblique originates from the 5th – 8th ribs, and insert at several points (linea alba, iliac spine, pubic crest, and the iliac crest).

The functions of the external oblique are to aid in rotation (chopping down a tree), flexion (bending over), and lateral flexion of the spine (bending to the side).

muscles.name: Biceps
muscles.description: The biceps brachii is one of the most often trained muscles. stereotypically most guys want big biceps - and in practice, this is often true. As is commonly known, the main function of the biceps brachii is elbow flexion (what occurs during a curl exercise). However, the biceps have far more responsibilities than just curls.

muscles.name: Triceps
muscles.description: The triceps are a muscle with three heads, hence the name. Those heads are the long head, lateral head, and medial head. The triceps are traditionally considered a powerhouse due to their overwhelmingly fast twitch. This expression refers to muscle fibers which expend energy quickly, and the triceps are particularly dominant in this trait. The triceps are involved during any pushing movement.

The triceps are traditionally considered a powerhouse due to their overwhelmingly fast twitch. This expression refers to muscle fibers which expend energy quickly, and the triceps are particularly dominant in this trait. The triceps are involved during any pushing movement.

muscles.name: Chest
muscles.description:
Primarily, there are three chest muscles involved in movement: the pectoralis major, the pectoralis minor, and the serratus anterior.

Pectoral muscles are most predominantly associated with movement of the shoulders and arms. When working together, they provide stability for bone structures such as the clavicle (collar bone) and the scapula (shoulder). Muscles of the chest enable us to lift, extend, and rotate our arms, along with playing a part in the process of respiration. Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

Chest muscles are required in order to carry out everyday activities like moving furniture, lifting heavy objects, pitching a baseball, and stretching our arms.

muscles.name: Calves
muscles.description: The calves are composed of two muscles, the gastrocnemius, and the soleus. Both muscles are active every time the ankle joint flexes. In other words, the calves are involved every time you take a step, stand up, or jump.

muscles.description:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.
muscles.description_en_us:
The quadriceps consist of four heads (hence the name quadriceps). The heads are: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.

With the exception of the rectus femoris, all of the heads of the quadriceps have one function, which is extending the knee.

That means that the quadriceps are active every time you walk or stand up. Additionally, and in conjunction with the hamstrings, the quadriceps stabilizes the knee.
